author: {'steamid': '76561197970910841', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 3045, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2257, 'last_played': 1414261688}
review:
This game is not winning any graphical awards; it looks a bit 8 bit retro, except that isn't intentional, I think. The tactical battles are not interactive. The interface is workable, although it's easy to notice details that could be smoother. The soundscape is middling to fair, mostly due to the soundtrack and not the effects.

But the gameplay is great. The variety in factions and how they play is great. You have 17 factions. None of them are all that good. The 'holy church of El' wants to break the seals and release the apocalypse. The deep ones... yeah. Necromancers, Demonologist, and a Troll King. Holy Priestess? Nope, worshipping a demon god. There are a few that are not intrinsically evil, I think that's about as far as you can stretch it in the alignment scale. Still, to illustrate the factional differences.. the Troll King is awesome in battle. He can lay waste to armies on his own. (And at start, that's what you have to do). But after a while, an overly critical mum sends a cauldron of gold because you're not doign so well. That helps a lot, you can finally buy a few units... and then suddenly the dread message: Mum is coming over to take over because her bumbling son is an idiot. New unit spawns in the HQ: Mom. Which is a troll witch of considerable skill, and a definite gamechanger.

You don't get high price games that try to pull all the wacky, wonderful, or scary stuff going around here. It is described as a 'strategy rogue-like', a surprisingly apt description. Your grand armies can be destroyed in moments and your empire reduced to crumbling ruins by a bad choice, it is fast-paced and light-hearted. I can highly recommend this to anyone who want a novel take on the fantasy wargame genre... and at the price*? It's a no-brainer.

* Steam sale, at time of writing.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969039327', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 911, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 588, 'last_played': 1448476163}
review:
Sid Meier said that good games are a series of interesting choices. This game fits that bill, in spades.

The genius of this game is that the interesting choices start on Turn 1 of this turn based strategy game, and they never let up. There is no down time. Do you go for that coal mine, even though that will leave you far from your home base? Do you even have an army that can win, if you do decide to attack? Should you wait a couple turns to summon more creatures, even though you really, really, really need that gold? Did you leave enough defenders at your home base? Shold I save up my Druid herbs to upgrade my apprentice, or should I spend them now to better go on the offensive? The interesting choices never stop, all through the game.

However...

If you just fire it up and click Start New Game, you won't know how to do anything, you'll think the game is stupid, the graphics are ugly, the UI is unintuitive (actually, this part is kinda true) and never play it again. This happened to me, in fact. This is an old fashioned game. You gotta use the manual, I won't say read the manual, but use it. Leave it open while you play and Alt-Tab. If the game clicks for you, after a game or two you will be dying to read the manual all the way through. But it's gonna take a bit of work at the beginning because of the wonky UI. I think your effort will be richly rewarded.

This game is easily worth full price, and if you can catch it on sale, it's the steal of the century.

review:
Very fun, very deep. Overall, highly recommended. 

My only complaint is the sheer number of 'critters' (i.e. deer, snakes, etc.) that run around on the map. I've had times when virtually every tile is covered with them. As soon as I kill them, there are a million more. Plus, how the hell can a single deer take over a whole town?!??! Would a deer wandering into a village really bring production to a halt???

I'd recommend "lairs", where a large concentration of one type of creature lives and which spawns mobs until cleared out. That way you could use these animals strategically - clear them out if you don't want them, or leave them active between you and your enemy so that he'll have to go through a bunch of moose or whatever to get to you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052783742', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 432, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 369, 'last_played': 1447738977}
review:
A bit of an Empire Management Roguelike. I lost within 10 minutes of my first game, which is exactly how I like my games to start. Conquest of Elysium 3 is a simple game. Move, attack, trade. recruit, etc. But while the mechanics themselves are simple, they're executed perfectly, and set the framework for what's really a complex strategy game.

The game offers 17 starting characters, all of which have their own unique playstyle and mechanics. The Baron can enlist locals to defend their towns and villages free of charge; the Necromancer can reanimate the dead to aid in battle, etc. etc. During combat your commanders might find magic items to aid in their conquest. I've only encountered one so far, which was the Bottle of Living Water. This item let my commander summon a powerful Water Elemental during battle. Awesome.

The amount of factions to try, and the amount of combinations to make while recruiting soldiers for your armies is insane. This game is definitely worth the price.

Witches need to collect mushrooms from forests and swamps to summon creatures. 
Necromancers must find places with lots of dead bodies to grow their army. 
Dwarves have one female dwarf in the city that gives birth to dwarf workers...

So while it doesnt look like much, it actually is a really fun and addictive game!

Just watch out for those deer taking over your castle...

author: {'steamid': '76561197998362614', 'num_games_owned': 244, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 7502, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7249, 'last_played': 1454298571}
review:
This is my first steam review... yay!  CoE3 is a nicely put together Turn-Based Stradegy game.  It reminds me a lot of Master of Magic.  There is no control in combat, and the game does not focus on research or city building, but instead, the acquisition of units and capture of cities/towns/villages/mines/outposts/towers/etc.  With each capture, you increase your income, build your army, and set out to explore the map and find and conquer your enemies.

There are numberous races in this game, and most of them play differently.  It's enough to keep me interested to keep playing and learning how they each work.  There are a massive number of unique units, there are magic items you can find and equip, and random world events which can be good or bad... losing a town due to a meteor is never fun, but it sure keeps it interesting!

The game has multiplayer as well.  My friend and I play all the time, and I can say after numerous games, that this is a stable, polished, and enjoyable game to play, either single-player or multiplayer.  If you are into the turn-based world domination, my army is bigger than yours but not necessarily better type games, which offer randomly generated maps, exploration, and a whole bunch of other cool stuff, I'd highly recommend this one.

The learning curve for CoE3 is a bit steep, but most of the information you can find in the games manual.  The graphics are not top-notch, but if you grew up on 90's gaming, the nostalgia is great!

review: A fantastic hybrid of roguelikes and 4X strategy games like Civilization. The great strength of this game is in the number and diversity of the factions available to play. There are seventeen factions total, allowing play as anything from a mighty Baron of men to the High Priest of an Elder God cult. All factions have unique and highly individualized play styles that will keep you going for potentially hundreds of hours. On top of the various factions the world itself is full of danger. Bandits, monsters and the ghosts that rise from the fields of battles present plenty of danger in their own right. From the makers of the Dominions series, this game offeres similar depth while being more accessible.

review:
Un juego donde te llevará al mundo de Elysium entre las pseudoedades; preclásica, clásica, caida del imperio romano y medieval, con más de 1000 monstruos totalmente diferentes, con cientos de elementos mágicos y hechizos.

Su creador de mapas aleatorios desde de cero añadirá un sin fin de partidas sin aburrimiento ni rutinas, lo malo de eso es que pueda que empiezes con asentamientos muy malos. Las 18 clases cada una con diferentes habilidades y elementos harán todas las clases totalmente únicas.

El juego en sí es bastante complicado por la cantidad de cosas, pero cuando le pillas el truco, tendrás inagotables partidas entretenidas y afables.

El mejor juego de fantasía que he jugado, incansable es este juego, divertido hasta el fin, y con un precio muy asequible.

review: This game is about as old-school as you can get without whipping out a floppy disk.  Its layout, graphics, and gameplay could probably have all been programmed with technology available in the late 80's.  But, even with all of that, this is one of the most interesting strategy games I have ever played.  The world and mythos are unique (even though the maps themselves are randomly generated), the magical powers of each leader are distinct and interesting (each of the 17 or so races has completely different game mechanics), and the wide range of creatures and events make this game compelling far beyond what screenshots would suggest. If you like grand strategy or were a fan of the old Lords of Magic, give this a try.

review:
Vestiremo i panni di un lord signore a caso, che possiede una bella base/cittadella, poche altre unità e un unico scopo: far fuori tutto ciò che non appartiene al proprio esercito. Lungo la mappa, ogni volta creata in maniera casuale, possiamo trovare villaggi, castelli, città, fattorie e località più o meno speciali che dovremo conquistare passandoci sopra, ma che potremo perdere altrettando facilmente. Una volta ho perso perchè due briganti idioti (e quando dico due intendo due) son passati sopra la mia cittadella, lasciata da me stupidamente sguarnita. Tedio. Così, comincia la nostra avanzata: ogni struttura conquistata ci fornirà risorse, e più risorse avremo più carne da macello potremmo assoldare, e così via fino alla conquista totale. Se vi sembra ripetitivo e semplice è perchè, difatti, lo è. In una ventina di minuti, in barba al manuale e alla mancanza di tutorial, capirete bene le meccaniche e potrete giocare spensierati. Anzi, verrete colti dalla sindrome del "ancora un turno e poi smetto".

Leggi l'Astrorecensione su: http://theshelternetwork.com/conquest-elysium-3-botte-da-ogre-orbi/

review:
I don't think that this will be a Game everyone is going to enjoy, but I am having a blast with it and it is a good, solid turn-based Strategy game. 
The Graphics are not the focus of the Game, they're focused mainly on conveying information on Terrain types and showing Armies/Monsters. The real work went into the Rule-set, Gameplay, and 17 different playable Races/Classes that each have unique strengths & weaknesses. Add to those 17 Classes the epic number & variety of wandering independent monsters and the fact that Maps are randomly generated (a Map Editor is included to create your own, as well) and the replayability value of the Game is pretty impressive!

review: Conquest of Elysium 3 is a fun and addicting game that focuses on empire building, randomly generated events and row-based stacks of doom. Each class plays the game entirely differently, and there are plenty of resources to collect for each specialized class or champion unit, meaning you're always on the hunt for more, and you will never be happy with just your initial borders. The learning curve really isn't that high, predominantly because the hardest parts involve figuring out how to garrison troops effectively as well as the different strengths and weaknesses of the randomly generated monsters guarding resources on the map. Everything after that is simple common sense. (Attacking a Hydra with only 10 generic soldiers? You deserve to lose. Duh.) At the time of purchase, this game was only $9. So there is no excuse, as Conquest of Elysium 3 is well worth any strategy gamer's collection, especially after they get bored of the guaranteed classics like XCOM:EU.

review:
A classic-style strategy game with a massive number of classes to choose from.  Each of the unique classes have their own strengths and weaknesses that provide a high level of entertainment.  The economy system is extremely innovative as different classes (armies) gather different types of resources from the same terrain.  For example, a Baron (the knightly themed army) gathers an increased amount of gold from his villages and towns but finds little of value on forest squares, while a Druid gathers plants from the wild to produce his special units.

A very unique, yet nostalgic feel to this game.  I highly recommend it.

review:
So take a war game, mix in some territory and resource aspects, and give it a dose of the crazy units and traits of Dominions 3, and you have this.    The various factions that you can pick all play dramatically diffrent from one another, from the Troll King who just barrels through the world on his own, to the Hoburgs who rely on converting farms to more profitable things, the dwarves who have to rely on the player's ability to keep troop supply lines in mind, or even some dumb wizards who can go and get themselves killed by their own summons (Plus more crazy shit).
The game is also very moddable and you can get new maps/units/factions made/installed pretty easily.

If you don't mind some old ass looking graphics and some old timey IP-address hookup for multi, this is totally something you should get.
